items.title: Strange interaction with multiple greenlets with the same parent and asyncio/coroutine/generator
items.body:
I was experimenting with the example provided in the [documentation](https://greenlet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#introduction) and I noticed a strange behavior when using asyncio.
This is an example script:
```py
import asyncio
import greenlet

def syncg():
    print("before g2")
    print("g2 result", syncg2.switch())
    print("after g2")

def g2sync():
    print("in g2")
    return 42

syncg1 = greenlet.greenlet(syncg)
syncg2 = greenlet.greenlet(g2sync)
print("sync version")
print("sync result", syncg1.switch())

async def asyncg():
    print("before g2")
    print("g2 result", asyncg2.switch())
    print("after g2")

def g2async():
    print("in g2")
    return 42

asyncg1 = greenlet.greenlet(asyncg)
asyncg2 = greenlet.greenlet(g2async)
print("asyncio version")
print("asyncio result", asyncio.run(asyncg1.switch()))
```

My understanding is that these two cases should be equal and print the lines `"before g2"` and `"in g2"` and return 42.
The async version resumes the execution of asyncg1 after asyncg2 exits instead.
This is the output:
```
sync version
before g2
in g2
sync result 42
asyncio version
before g2
in g2
g2 result 42
after g2
asyncio result None
```

python: 3.8.3
greenlet: 0.4.16

I tested on windows but the same behavior happen on linux

items.title: Undefined symbols for Linux wheels deployed to WSL
items.body:
### Background
For a variety of reasons, we are required to only deploy wheels we build from source.  To facilitate this, we simply build the wheels we need in a Linux system (CentOS 7) and store them in a private PyPi repo so we can consume them easily later.

### Problem
We've begun using Linux via the Windows 10 WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux) and it works extremely well (no more cygwin).  However, when we install the greenlet wheel we built in CentOS into Ubuntu 18.04 WSL, we get undefined symbol errors when we try to use it.

The specific symbols in the greenlet.foo.so file are AnnotateIgnoreReadsBegin and AnnotateIgnoreReadsEnd.  Both of those seem to be controlled from /usr/include/python*/dynamic_annotations.h via a #ifdef for DYNAMIC_ANNOTATIONS_ENABLED.  I think this is related to [PEP-3107](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3107/), [PEP-483](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0483/), and [PIP-484](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/) but I could be totally wrong about that.

In any case, if I build the greenlet wheel directly in Ubuntu 18.04 WSL, those symbols are not included in the greenlet.*.so file.  The wheel built in WSL and in CentOS show themselves to be for an arch of linux, (greenlet-0.4.14-foo-bar-linux_x86_64.whl) so there's nothing to distinguish one build from the other beyond the actual symbols that appear in the .so file.

What I can't seem to find is why/where DYNAMIC_ANNOTATIONS_ENABLED gets flipped between one system and the other.  Both are running the same versions of python (3.4 but I've reproduced it on 3.5 as well using the same systems).  I didn't see anything in the greenlet code that would flip that but this is well beyond my normal python experience.

### The Ask
I simply don't know where to look next - I'm not even sure where or with whom the problem lies (me, greenlet, WSL, something else?).  A google search was unhelpful - lots of people seeing similar problems with no one actually saying how to solve it beyond "just install from source".

Is this something that you've seen?  Do you have any pointers on where I can look or what I can try so that I can have one wheel that works in both a "normal" Linux environment as well as a WSL Linux environment?

### Workaround
For now, I've simply created a constraint.txt file for our project that we can use in the WSL environment (the constraint is to never install greenlet from a wheel - only source installs) and that works but it also means people aren't testing locally against what we ship so is less than ideal.

items.title: Fix wrong platform inclusion for mingw64
items.body:
#### Expected behavior `pip3 install neovim` should work on mingw64 mintty session. #### Actual behavior Neovim python client requires greenlet. Because greenlet does not support mingw64, it crashes as `greenlet` mistakenly selects `switch_amd64_unix.h` for mingw64. The crash is due to the fact that `sizeof(long)` is different on UNIX and MINGW64, 8 and 4, respectively. #### How to reproduce - Install 64-bit [MSYS2](https://github.com/msys2/msys2/wiki/MSYS2-installation). - Start a mingw64 session. - Install python3 and pip3 for mingw64 (not for msys2) using pacman. - Run `pip3 install neovim` and it will crash. Here are my [first](https://github.com/python-greenlet/greenlet/pull/124) and [second](https://github.com/python-greenlet/greenlet/pull/125) attempts to fix greenlet for mingw64. The second PR is merged. If you `git clone` the merged branch you can now build it with `python3 setup.py build` and install with `python3 setup.py install`. After installation `pip3 install neovim` works.
Posted on Utopian.io - Rewarding Open Source Contributors

items.title: What is _stack_saved for?
items.body: I can't really think of a good reason why I'd want to find out how much of the stack is saved on the heap. Why is this exposed?

items.title: How does g_switch throw an exception in the target greenlet if an exception is set?
items.body: It seems, based on the implementation of green_throw and a few other things, that if an exception is set, g_switch will throw it in the target greenlet. But looking at g_switchstack, I don't understand how that can work. It seems to save the current set exception in the current greenlet, then restore the exception from the target greenlet, thus overwriting the currently set exception with (often) nothing. How does it work?

items.title: something err
items.body:
from greenlet import greenlet


gr1 = None
gr2 = None


def test1():
    print 12
    print('test1', gr2)
    gr2.switch()
    print 34


def test2():
    print 56
    gr1.switch()
    print 78


def main():
    gr2 = greenlet(test2)
    gr1 = greenlet(test1)
    print(gr1, gr2)
    gr1.switch()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

log:

items.title: Greenlet 0.4.10 wheel doesn't work on python 2.7.3
items.body:
https://pypi.python.org/packages/fd/4b/108108a5a4234b2c7f81a7e9513950caf5146c9b2d47664348dbe9aebaf8/greenlet-0.4.10-cp27-cp27mu-manylinux1_x86_64.whl#md5=eb175d2b16766004abc16f5b23a8ad99  Fails on python 2.7.3. It raises 
`ImportError: /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/greenlet.so: undefined symbol: _PyTrash_thread_deposit_object` This looks to be a duplicate of issue #39, the wheel was built with Python >=2.7.4. And since pip simply says the wheel is compatible with cp27	, pip installs a broken wheel.

items.title: Windows 64-bit DLL is broken
items.body:
Using greenlet version 0.4.10 on Python 2.7 64-bit on Windows (ActiveState distribution) gives the following bug:
`>>> import greenlet
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ImportError: DLL load failed: The specified procedure could not be found.`

items.title: Using make-manylinux
items.body:
How is the `make-manylinux` script supposed to be used? If I try to invoke it standalone, I get:

```
$ ./make-manylinux 
/bin/bash: /greenlet/make-manylinux: Permission denied

```

items.title: Import error with python 3
items.body:
Hi all. Noob here.

I simply can't get greenlet to work with python 3

I tried reinstalling greenlet this way:
`sudo pip install greenlet --target=/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/`

but I still can't get it to work. I keep getting the greenlet import error (undefined symbol: _Py_ZeroStruct). 

```
pi@raspberrypi:~ $ python3
Python 3.4.2 (default, Oct 19 2014, 13:31:11) 
[GCC 4.9.1] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import greenlet
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ImportError: /usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/greenlet.so: undefined symbol: _Py_ZeroStruct
>>> 
```

when I use python 2.7 i get no error:

```
pi@raspberrypi:~ $ python
Python 2.7.9 (default, Mar  8 2015, 00:52:26) 
[GCC 4.9.2] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import greenlet
>>> greenlet
<module 'greenlet' from '/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/greenlet-0.4.10-py2.7-linux-armv7l.egg/greenlet.so'>
>>> 
```

Can anyone help me solve this issue?

items.title: manylinux1 packaging
items.body:
Thank you so much for creating this awesome project!  I am the author of the
sphinxserve package that uses greenlet and gevent dependencies for concurrency.
Until recently linux users had to manually compile python bindings which
historically has been a major drawback. All that is changing with the
introduction of pep-513 and the superb work of the pypa/manylinux team who pushed the
issue and created the needed tooling including a docker image.

Do you think it would be possible to release manylinux1 greenlet wheels on pypi?

To make things as easy as possible here is a small shellscript that only 
depends on docker. It automatically downloads the manylinux image and create
the wheels on the current directory.

```
[admin@delphy tmp]$ cat build_greenlet.sh 
#!/usr/bin/env bash

CMD=$(cat << 'EOF'
cd /io
for version in 27 34 35; do
    /opt/python/cp${version}-cp${version}m/bin/pip wheel greenlet
    auditwheel repair greenlet*${version}*.whl
    rm greenlet*${version}*whl
done
mv wheelhouse/*whl .
rmdir wheelhouse
EOF
)

echo "$CMD" | docker run -i  -v `pwd`:/io quay.io/pypa/manylinux1_x86_64 /bin/bash
```

Stackless has a [`runcount` attribute](http://stackless.readthedocs.org/en/latest/library/stackless/stackless.html#stackless.runcount) which returns the number of runable tasklets.

items.title: 0.4.6 Won't Compile Under Python 2.5
items.body:
In commit 6a2d69dc1de25d7a623b5cfd835d13bc36eab8d0 a call to the function `PyLong_FromSsize_t` was added, but according to [the documentation](https://docs.python.org/2/c-api/long.html#c.PyLong_FromSsize_t) this function is only available in 2.6 and above.

This leads to the following compile error:

```
greenlet.c: In function ‘green_get_stack_saved’:
greenlet.c:1232:2: warning: implicit declaration of function ‘PyLong_FromSsize_t’ [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
greenlet.c:1232:2: warning: return makes pointer from integer without a cast [enabled by default]
```

And of course the resulting `ImportError`:

```
python2.5 -c 'import greenlet; print (greenlet, greenlet.__version__)'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
ImportError: /usr/lib/python2.5/site-packages/greenlet.so: undefined symbol: PyLong_FromSsize_t
```

items.title: del coroutine effect
items.body:
```
from greenlet import greenlet

def main():
    entry_fun_cortion.switch(0)
    entry_fun_cortion.switch(1)
    entry_fun_cortion.switch(2)
    entry_fun_cortion.switch(3)
    entry_fun_cortion.switch(4)
    entry_fun_cortion.switch(5)

count = 0
def entry_fun(test):
    global main_cortione, count,entry_fun_cortion
    while True:
        count += 1
        print ("before switch id %d"%id(entry_fun_cortion))
        aid = main_cortione.switch()
        if count == 2:
            del entry_fun_cortion
            print "after del"   # continue to excute , and get id 2
            entry_fun_cortion = greenlet(entry_fun)

        print ("id ", id(entry_fun_cortion))
        print "after get id ", aid


entry_fun_cortion = greenlet(entry_fun)
main_cortione = greenlet(main)
main_cortione.switch()
```

The output is 

before switch id 140539650621840
    ('id ', 140539650621840)
    after get id  1
    before switch id 140539650621840
    after del
    ('id ', 140539650623120)
    after get id  2
    before switch id 140539650623120
    before switch id 140539650623120
    ('id ', 140539650623120)
    after get id  4
    before switch id 140539650623120
    ('id ', 140539650623120)
    after get id  5
    before switch id 140539650623120

I am wondering why there is two continus line "before switch id 140539650623120",  I think I already del the old coroutine. It seem after del the coroutine , the func body can continue exec. If the new coroutine can work , why it can't get the id 3 ?

items.title: Release wheels for greenlet
items.body:
[Wheels](http://wheel.readthedocs.org/en/latest/) are the cool new way to release python packages/distributions. Why are they better? They're more self contained, they're more up to date than eggs, they can be installed by `pip` (eggs can't), they work well with such things as virtualenvs, they allow for binary extensions and such. They generally make python package installing easier. Here's their [pep](http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0427/#id3).

The immediate big win, if greenlet distributed wheels, is that windows users could easily install it using `pip install greenlet` and everything would just work, even under a windows virtualenv. This isn't the case for a windows installer package which can only install to the system python.

Now doing new-fangled release stuff always takes effort, I appreciate that, so if there's any way I can help or confusion I can explain please let me know.

The [wheel](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/wheel) package/tool comes with an extremely handy `wheel convert` command, which can convert a win installer package into a wheel! This could make it very easy to convert the [current released installers](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/greenlet#downloads) into wheel files.

Otherwise they add the `bdist_wheel` command to `setup.py` for building wheels from scratch.

An ulterior motive of mine is that I'd liked to help gevent release a wheel as well so it can also be installed on Windows easily. At the moment it has no windows binary distribution on pypi. Of course, it needs this package as a dependency first.

items.title: Tests broken with out-of-source builds
items.body:
The test suite basically converts an out-of-source build back into an ugly in-source build. Therefore, if multiple versions of the package are built from the same sources, the tests will work with only one of them properly.

I'm not sure if I understand the tests correctly but I believe that you rather should adjust `sys.path` within the tests to respect build-dir rather than linking the built files back into source dir.

items.title: greenlet.switch() raises a SystemError
items.body:
Very occasionally we get .switch() raising this exception on 0.3.3:

```
SystemError: error return without exception set
```

Which means switch returns an error status to the python api but did not set the exception state.  After a very quick look it seems like the return tuple of g_switch() is never checked for NULL, I have no idea what PyTuple_SetItem() would do if the tuple it has to operate on is NULL, but it is conceivable that it could end up clearing the exception state.  In any case, that failure path should probably not be undefined.

Another item that popped is the assumption in that function that args is always going to contain a valid python object.  I assume this was on purpose and correct, but am writing it down since I haven't traced it down yet so could be something to check.

I'll update our code to use 0.3.4 and see if we still see this with that version before investigating more thoroughly (is 0.4 due to be released soon? the NEWS file seems to suggest so).

Regards
Floris

items.title: greenlets leak thread local data when used with threads
items.body:
If greenlets are used with threads they will leak weak references to `_thread._localdummy` objects. These objects seem to be internally used in the interpreter to implement thread local storage.

Simple test case:

``` python
import threading
import greenlet

while 1:
    t = threading.Thread(target=greenlet.getcurrent)
    t.start()
    t.join()
```

I can reproduce this on OS X 32/64 bit in the latest 2.7 version as well as linux 32 bit, both running the 0.3.4 version of greenlet.

items.title: SIGSEGV on armhf
items.body:
The patch I have attached is not my best work, unfortunately. However, I was unable to get 0.3.3 to compile for armhf on Linux properly, nor could I get it to run the test suite without a segfault. So, the patch does two things:

-- Add -fomit-frame-pointer for armv7l/Linux builds so that r7 can be saved, and

-- Bring platform/switch_arm32_gcc.h up-to-date with 0.3.4 (the messy part if you try to apply the patch) and -- the important bit -- makes it more conservative about what gets saved on switch. It may be saving too much.

With the patch, I can get the Debian unstable version of 0.3.3 to build and run the test suite. I have not tried this with top of tree but hopefully it isn't too difficult to figure out how to make the same changes.

Thanks.

items.title: compile on Debian on Sparc
items.body: We could not get the python-greenlet package to compile on our Debian host running on sparc hardware using gcc.  I modified the slp_platformselect.h file to remove the test for SunOS when including the platform/switch_sparc_sun_gcc.h file.  I modified the platform/switch_sparc_sun_gcc.h file to remove the include of sys/trap.h and defined ST_FLUSH_WINDOWS to be 3.  I will attempt to upload my patch files

items.title: Idea: be a mock package if platform is PyPy
items.body:
Various packages like eventlet have greenlet as a dependency but it so happens that PyPy has builtin greenlet support and the greenlet package doesn't even compile on it.
Hence I'm suggesting that greenlet's setup.py attempts to detect if running on PyPy and if so, leave the extensions uncompiled and just run as a mock package. This should allow all packages that depend on greenlet to run on PyPy unchanged. According to personal tests greenlet package doesn't show up on PyPy even if installed but it will continue to use the builtin greenlet support instead.

items.title: Idea: greenlet switch detection callback
items.body:
First, a fairy story: I have a very big system based on greenlet at work, with dozens of plugins and thousands of greenlets, all in one process. Occasionaly, I notice that my system stalls with severe lags, where some instances of plugins might wait minutes in line for their turn to run. It's quite obvious that one of plugins contains a bug, likely doing something blocking, or maybe computing something for a bit too long. If only it was possible to know which plugin/function consumes CPU cycles the most!

As a side note: usual profiling tools don't work correctly. Others use hacks to detect greenlet switches, with workarounds for specific event libraries (e.g. gevent), and are not optimal. The most problematic case is when switch goes into C code. Python's settrace only traces on Python code, any switch to C code is invisible until trace resurfaces back in Python code, in some other greenlet, unknown time later.

I propose a new global function set_switch_callback that accepts a callback object as a parameter and returns previous callback object (None initially). The calback value of None would mean no callback is called. The callback would execute immediately before an actual C-level switch or throw with two parameters: current greenlet and target greenlet objects. The callback is only called when those differ, obviously. The callback is only set for the current thread, making it thread-safe and similar to settrace. Any exceptions raised by the callback will be raised by switch/throw instead of the intended action.

This way tracing and profiling code would be able to have a definite information about greenlet switches (and thus would be able to time them), even when switches are made between greenlets in C.

What do you think?

items.title: gcc 3.2 no longer works
items.body: Compiling greenlet with gcc 3.2 (RHEL3) no longer works.  The assembler generated by for calling the functions by pointers is different then from the 0.3.1 release but I can't figure out why.  Also to my untrained eye both generated assembler files seem like they should work.
